Skyrocketing insulin prices have forced too many Arizonans to choose between paying their bills or getting the medicine they need. I helped introduce legislation to change that by capping out-of-pocket insulin costs at $35 a month.

Arizonans are paying some of the highest gas prices we‚Äôve seen in years. To help Arizona families save money at the pump, I introduced a bill to suspend the federal gas tax for the rest of the year. At about 18 cents per gallon, it adds up quick.

After seeing labor shortages in the trucking industry further disrupt supply chains, I introduced bipartisan legislation to ease the bottleneck by cutting red tape to boost our trucking workforce so essential supplies and goods can get across our country faster.

Supply chain challenges like the microchip shortage are a major factor behind rising prices, so I‚Äôm working to fix them. I negotiated a plan to bring microchip manufacturing back to America that would create great-paying jobs in Arizona and help us compete with China.

From groceries, to gas, to prescription drugs ‚Äî rising prices are hurting Arizona families trying to get back on their feet. 

Lowering costs for Arizonans is a top priority of mine. 

And this is how I‚Äôm working to do it. üëá

The American citizen from #StatenIsland and his wife that my office has been helping for weeks to safely evacuate from #Ukraine through Moldova have arrived in the United States.

The current bias in the appraisal process has harmed communities of color for far too long. Join @FSCDems tomorrow as we investigate this problem and discuss solutions. (5/5)

This shift has not eliminated bias in appraising. In 2018, homes in neighborhoods where 50% of residents are Black are valued 50% less than areas with no Black residents. In most Black neighborhoods, Black owned houses are undervalued on average by $48,000 per home. (4/5)

While there are multiple factors to this issue, bias in the home valuation process is a barrier for communities of color. The appraisal industry lacks diversity and has shifted from independent appraisers to automatic processes. (3/5)

In 2019, homeownership increased, and during the pandemic, equity rose by over 29%. However, communities of color were consistently locked out of the benefits of this housing boom. According to one study, homeownership makes up ~27% of the Black-White wealth gap. (2/5)

Housing is a human right. Period. 

Tomorrow, @FSCDems are holding a hearing to learn more about how bias in the housing appraisal process hurts homeowners and disproportionately affects people of color. (1/5) https://financialservices.house.gov/events/eventsingle.aspx?EventID=409150#Webcast
